features, not simply methods.
 
I see too distinct cases here: (1) tools that will generate stubs (like JBuilder 6 as I read in this
string of notes) and (2) tools that will automatically produce some test cases for you (like JTest,
which I personally use).
 
1. Let's start with the first set of tools:
 
Starting from scratch or even from automatically generated empty stubs may have some immediate
effect on a small code base (less than 20.000 lines of code) , as you are likely to have more insight
on what the code actually does.
 
On a larger project, I agree that the initial benefit is reduced, but there is a tangible benefit of having
the initial unit test *structure* in place. On the long run, people adding new features, or even maintaining
the already existing ones, will have something to build upon instead of stumbling everytime with the very
same request the original author posted in this list.
 
2. As for JTest, it will do even something else for you, which is to come up (through reflection
and some other techniques) with a basic set of unit tests that can be manually augmented later
 
>> I would be very curious to know if anyone can report on actual (measured, quantitative) experiences
>> that either support or refute this.
 
This is a comparison between no coverage and no structure for automated unit test and
some coverage and a initial foundation for automated unit testing. From past experience,
the first group is working on chaos and doesn't have any metric to be compared against
the second group of people. Usually, when you ask these teams how much improvement
they've got from establishing any kind of process you just receive a "it is much better now"
response.

From: Alan Bram
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, March 18, 2002 1:41 PM
Subject: [junit] RE: Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?

In this discussion, apparently we have been talking about "retrofitting" unit tests for old code that never before had them. The notion seems to be that each method in a class, or perhaps each public method, should have a unit test.
 
I think this is wrong. I think, as J.B. said, that in such a case you should concentrate on testing features, not simply methods.
 
I would say that for new code, where you're writing tests along with your production code, it might make sense to try for a test per (public) method. But that's because in this case you have the benefit of thinking about the testing at the time you're writing the code. I think you're more likely to design your code in such a way as to have this make more sense. (The "testing influences design" notion.)
 
The problem I see with mindlessly (or even mindfully) writing a test for each method, just to satisfy someone's idea that code coverage is good, is that you're likely to (1) invest a lot of (or even a little) time; and (2) generate a lot of test code (which will have to be maintained, don't forget), for what will turn out to be little or no benefit. I would bet that the marginal number of bugs found by "complete" per-method tests over a more sensible per-feature approach, both now and forever in the future, is very close to zero. At least that's my impression based on my own experiences.
 
More is not always better.
 
I would be very curious to know if anyone can report on actual (measured, quantitative) experiences that either support or refute this.
 
 - Alan Bram
